question: Which of the following steps are included in the Plan Do Check Act (PDCA) problem solving framework?

question: Which of the following is NOT one of the 7 basic quality tools?

explanations.a: A histogram is one of the 7 basic quality tools. It is a chart that shows the frequency distribution of a set of data.
explanations.b: A scatter diagram is one of the 7 basic quality tools. It is used to show the relationship between two variables.
explanations.c: A control chart is one of the 7 basic quality tools. It is used to monitor a process over time to determine if it is stable and within control limits.
explanations.d: A Pareto chart is one of the 7 basic quality tools. It is a bar graph that shows the relative frequency or size of problems in descending order of importance.
explanations.e: Force field analysis is not one of the 7 basic quality tools. It is a technique used in organizational development to analyze the forces that drive and restrain a proposed change.

question: Which of the following is an example of a Lean tool used to identify and eliminate waste?

explanations.d: 5S is a Lean tool used to identify and eliminate waste. It stands for Sort, Set in Order, Shine, Standardize, and Sustain.

question: Which of the following is NOT one of the 5 principles of Six Sigma?

explanations.a: Focusing on the customer is one of the core principles of Six Sigma, as the ultimate goal of any improvement project is to satisfy the customer's needs.
explanations.b: Continuous improvement is one of the core principles of Six Sigma, as the goal is to constantly improve processes and eliminate defects.
explanations.c: Defect prevention is one of the core principles of Six Sigma, as the goal is to prevent defects from occurring in the first place rather than fixing them after the fact.
explanations.d: Statistical thinking is one of the core principles of Six Sigma, as data analysis and statistical tools are used to measure, analyze, and improve processes.
explanations.e: Just-in-time manufacturing is not one of the core principles of Six Sigma, although it is a Lean manufacturing concept that emphasizes the importance of producing goods only when they are needed, reducing inventory, and eliminating waste.
